Package com.nickbenn.adventofcode.day02

Class CubeConundrum

java.lang.Object
com.nickbenn.adventofcode.day02.CubeConundrum
public class CubeConundrum extends Object
Implements solutions to the Day 2 problem, involving random drawing of colored cubes from a bag.

Parts 1 and 2 of the problem differ in the information that must be inferred from the input data (which consists of the number of blocks of each color selected in 1 or more draws in each game):

  • For part 1, the sumFeasibleGames(Map) must return the sum of game IDs for all games in the input file that could occur with specified (in CEILINGS) number of red, green, and blue cubes.
  • For part 2, the sumPower() method must find the smallest number of cubes of each color which would make each of the games feasible, compute the product of these numbers for each game, and return the sum of these products.
See Also:
  • "Day 2: Cube Conundrum".

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type
    Method
    Description
    static void
    main(String[] args)
    Creates an instance of CubeConundrum for each of the two parts of the problem, implicitly specifying that input should be read from the file given by DataSource.DEFAULT_INPUT_FILE, and invoking the relevant method to compute the required value, which is then printed to the console.
    int
    sumFeasibleGames(Map<String,Integer> ceilings)
    Computes the sum of IDs of all games that would be feasible with the cube color limits specified in ceilings.
    long
    sumPower()
    Computes and returns the sum of the power of all games, where the power of a game is defined as the product of the minimum numbers of red, green, and blue cubes required to produce the color draws read from the input file.

      public static final Map<String,Integer> CEILINGS
      Maximum numbers of red, green, and blue cubes allowed for feasible games in part 1.

  • Constructor Details

    • CubeConundrum

      public CubeConundrum()
      Initializes this instance, using the value of DataSource.DEFAULT_INPUT_FILE as the name (relative to the package of this class on the classpath) of the file to be read. In other words, using this constructor is equivalent to using CubeConundrum(DataSource.DEFAULT_INPUT_FILE).

    • CubeConundrum

      public CubeConundrum(String inputFile)
      Initializes this instance, using the value specified in the inputFile parameter as the name (relative to the package of this class on the classpath) of the file to be read.
      Parameters:
      inputFile - Classpath/package-relative location of file from which input is read.

  • Method Details

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args) throws IOException
      Creates an instance of CubeConundrum for each of the two parts of the problem, implicitly specifying that input should be read from the file given by DataSource.DEFAULT_INPUT_FILE, and invoking the relevant method to compute the required value, which is then printed to the console.
      Parameters:
      args - Command-line arguments (currently ignored).
      Throws:
      IOException - If the input file specified (implicitly or explicitly) in the constructor invocation cannot be found or read.

    • sumFeasibleGames

      public int sumFeasibleGames(Map<String,Integer> ceilings) throws IOException
      Computes the sum of IDs of all games that would be feasible with the cube color limits specified in ceilings.

      This method does not modify the state of the instance or have any other side effects.

      Parameters:
      ceilings - Map<String,Integer> giving the maximum number of cubes of each color.
      Throws:
      IOException - If the input file specified (implicitly or explicitly) in the constructor invocation cannot be found or read.

    • sumPower

      public long sumPower() throws IOException
      Computes and returns the sum of the power of all games, where the power of a game is defined as the product of the minimum numbers of red, green, and blue cubes required to produce the color draws read from the input file.

      This method does not modify the state of the instance or have any other side effects.

      Throws:
      IOException - If the input file specified (implicitly or explicitly) in the constructor invocation cannot be found or read.
